FRIDAY, OCTOBER 7 1938

Next Friday we begin
again the dreary round of
electing class officers. In all
probability, most of those
elected will be picked out
of a hat by a bunch of the
boys in a smoke-filled room.
There is no reason to be particularly exercised about
this fact. The University's future hardly hangs in the
balance over the choice of a freshman class sergeant-atarmsBut there is one phase of the pending elections
which is important for every undergraduate. A student
council representative will be elected from each of
three classes. At this moment, the University is particularly agitated over the recent "purge" of activities and
their leaders. We can fin) no better way to test the
implications of the new program than in the coming
Council elections.
It has been a long-standing custom around her 't
pick Student Council members pretty much by ear. The
NEWS-LETTER, in its feeble fashion has been protesting
this state of affairs for longer than we care to admit.
Suffice it to say that Council aspirants still run for
election without making the slightest attempt to present
their views to the campus.
In this case, such silence is well-nigh inexcusable.
The Council's recent decisions seem to us both wise and
just. But they are certainly controversial. No candidate
worth his salt can still be entirely open-minded about
them.
Every student who is interested in voting in the
coming election has a right to know who he is voting
for. In the spirit of service, we again open our columns
to any candidate who wishes to present his views to his
electorate.
There are many issues which deserve the attention
of aspirants to office. We are still faced with an appalling lack of adequate publicity for the Council's future plans. The problem of compulsory assemblies is
bound to arise again in the future- Only a time-serving political hack could claim absolution from the duty
of taking a stand on these questions.
The time is corning when Student Council membership will be based on some conception of merit. For,
it is only in such a selection that any guarantee of future progress can be found.

prepares for full year
The International Relations club
met for its first meeting of the year
In Gilman 310 last Tuesday to discuss its organization and future
plans. Dr Lane, charman for the
meetings, explained to the group the
accomplishments of the club in former years, emphasizing the fact that
several noted speakers attended those
meetings.
Carnegie Endowment
Dr Lane also pointed out the advantages of the organization founded
by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. This endowment
has provided numerous books and
pamphlets which embrace the multitude of international problems. These
books were selected so they would
encourage the study of international
relations and thereby give the stu-

dents an unbiased opinion of world
affairs.
It was then suggested that the
club join the SAC, and become a
regular campus activity. The club
discussed this proposal and decided
to affiliate itself with the SAC.
International Problems
For future meetings, the club decided that each member should choose
an international problem and be prepared to report on it. Some of the
selected topics were: Mussolini, the
Ludlow amendment, the Mexican
situation, and
England's foreign
policy.

Invitation issued
For Goucher reception
Dr David Allan Robertson, president of Goucher college, and Mrs
Robertson have issued invitations to
a reception, October 15, at Goucher
hall, when the architectural drawings
in the Goucher college competition
will be on exhibition.
It is expected the winner of the
competition, whose name will be announced at exercises October 14, at
the Lyric, will be at the reception.
The exhibition will follow a luncheon to be attended by members of
the jury who are to decide the competition and by educators from other
colleges.
